You are searching for a \(x_m \in [0,12]\) such that

\(\int_0^{x_m}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx = \frac12 \int_0^{12}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx\).

hints_raw:
You can recycle your calculations from [http://wiki.ubc.ca/Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH103/April_2009/Question_5_(a) 5 (a)].

You also want to use the result from [http://wiki.ubc.ca/Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH103/April_2009/Question_5_(a) 5 (a)].
You are searching for a <math> x_m \in [0,12]\ </math> such that

<math>\int_0^{x_m}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx = \frac12 \int_0^{12}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx</math>.
question: 5 (c)
sols_html:
We are searching for a \(x_m \in [0,12]\) such that

\(\int_0^{x_m}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx = \frac12 \int_0^{12}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx = \frac12 96\pi = 48\pi\).

We calculate

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{x_m}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx &= \pi\int_0^{x_m}(14-x)dx \\ &= \pi\left.\left(14x - \frac{x^2}{2}\right)\right|_0^{x_m} \\ &= \pi\left(14x_m - \frac{x_m^2}{2}\right) = 48\pi\end{aligned}\]

We cancel the \(\pi\) and continue

\(0=x_m^2 - 28x_m + 96 = (x_m-24)(x_m-4)\)

\[\begin{aligned} x_{m_1}=4, x_{m_2}=24\end{aligned}\]

Since \(24\notin[0,12]\) we conclude \(x_m=4\).

You need to cut 4cm from \(x=0\).
sols_latex:
We are searching for a $x_m \in [0,12]$ such that

$\int_0^{x_m}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx = \frac12 \int_0^{12}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx = \frac12 96\pi = 48\pi$.

We calculate

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{x_m}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx &= \pi\int_0^{x_m}(14-x)dx \\
&= \pi\left.\left(14x - \frac{x^2}{2}\right)\right|_0^{x_m} \\
&= \pi\left(14x_m - \frac{x_m^2}{2}\right) = 48\pi
\end{align*}

We cancel the $\pi$ and continue

$0=x_m^2 - 28x_m + 96 = (x_m-24)(x_m-4)$

\begin{align*}
x_{m_1}=4, x_{m_2}=24
\end{align*}

Since $24\notin[0,12]$ we conclude $x_m=4$.

You need to cut 4cm from $x=0$.

We are searching for a <math> x_m \in [0,12]\ </math> such that

<math>\int_0^{x_m}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx = \frac12 \int_0^{12}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx = \frac12 96\pi = 48\pi</math>.

We calculate

:<math> \begin{align}
\int_0^{x_m}\left(\sqrt{14-x}\right)^2\pi dx &= \pi\int_0^{x_m}(14-x)dx \\
&= \pi\left.\left(14x - \frac{x^2}{2}\right)\right|_0^{x_m} \\
&= \pi\left(14x_m - \frac{x_m^2}{2}\right) = 48\pi
\end{align} </math>

We cancel the <math>\ \pi</math> and continue

<math> 0=x_m^2 - 28x_m + 96 = (x_m-24)(x_m-4)\ </math>

:<math> x_{m_1}=4, x_{m_2}=24 \ </math>

Since <math>\ 24\notin[0,12]</math> we conclude <math>x_m=4\ </math>.

You need to cut  4cm from <math> x=0</math>.
statement_html:
A carrot has the shape formed by revolving the region under the graph of

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \sqrt{14-x}\end{aligned}\]

for \(0 \leq x \leq 12\) cm about the x axis. The concentration of vitamin A is found to vary in the carrot with x according to

\[\begin{aligned} c(x) = \frac1{12} e^{-x/12} \frac{\text{mg}}{\text{cm}^3}\end{aligned}\]

You want to cut the carrot at a certain value of x, obtaining two pieces of equal volume. How many centimeters from x = 0 do you have to cut?
statement_raw:
A carrot has the shape formed by revolving the region under the graph of

:<math> f(x) = \sqrt{14-x} </math>

for <math> 0 \leq x \leq 12 </math> cm about the ''x'' axis. The concentration of vitamin A is found to vary in the carrot with ''x'' according to 

:<math> c(x) = \frac1{12} e^{-x/12} \frac{\text{mg}}{\text{cm}^3} </math>

[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH103_April_2009_Question_5_(a)_5a.png|350px]]

You want to cut the carrot at a certain value of ''x'', obtaining two pieces of equal volume. How many centimeters from ''x = 0'' do you have to cut?
